items.content: The performances are riveting and the visuals are stunning. The boxing sequences are brutally realistic - there are no crappy Rocky theatrics here - and the humanity oozes out of every scene.

items.author: Roger Ebert
items.content: The most painful and heartrending portrait of jealousy in the cinema--an "Othello'' for our times.

items.author: Gene Siskel
items.content: Filmed in black-and-white and shockingly well acted by De Niro, Raging Bull suggests that if you are looking for the source of evil in the world, you don't have to look any further than yourself. It's inside you or it isn't. And it comes out or it doesn't. [19 Dec 1980]
Another harsh character study, with poignant echoes of "Taxi Driver."

items.author: Sheila Benson
items.content: One of the bloodiest and most beautiful reflections on atonement in the Scorsese canon... It is still one of cinema's most breathtaking films.

items.author: Vincent Canby
items.content: The entire film is played at such high pitch it may well exhaust audiences that don't come prepared. And, at the heart of the film, there is the mystery of Jake himself, but that is what separates Raging Bull from all other fight movies, in fact, from most movies about anything. Raging Bull is an achievement.

items.author: James Berardinelli
items.content: Takes a cold, unflinching look at the violence both inside and outside of the ring.

items.author: Peter Travers
items.content: A fiercely poetic study of violence. Stunningly shot in black-and-white. [14 Dec 1989, p.23]

items.author: Jay Scott
items.content: The intensity of the film verges on the intolerable.

items.author: Dave Kehr
items.content: As LaMotta, Robert De Niro gives a blank, soulless performance; there's so little of depth or urgency coming from him that he's impossible to despise, or forgive, in any but the most superficial way.
